                         Home                                               Research                                               Faculty Research                                               Marine Biology Lab                                               Lab members                                                          Lab members                                                     Lab members                              Publications                              News & Events                                                                              Principal Investigator   Dr. John Burt, Ph.D., Associate Professor of Biology                                                                                                                                   University of Windsor, Canada. PhD, MS     Cape Breton University, Canada. BS     University of Sunderland, UK. PGCE     A marine biologist, John Burt uses the Arabian Gulf as a natural laboratory to study coral reef ecology in extreme environments and to understand how these may serve as a model for the possible impacts of future climate change on reefs elsewhere.       View profile                                                         Post Doctoral Researchers     Dr. Ed Smith, Ph.D                                                                                                                                   University of Southampton, UK. BSc, PhD   University College London/Imperial. MSc     Ed's PhD looked into the role of green fluorescent protein (GFP)-like pigments in corals. Since joing NYUAD in 2012, he has been investigating the mechanisms used by corals in the extreme conditions of the Gulf, in the hope of improving the understanding of whether/how corals will adapt to future climate change. Ed is also looking at the population structure and connectivity of corals within and outside of the Gulf.     View profile                                                           Dr. Emily Howells, Ph.D                                                                                                                                   James Cook University, Australia. BSc   Australian Institute of Marine Science (AIMS) Ph.D     Emily's PhD evaluated the importance of algal endosymbionts in shaping the thermal tolerance of corals. While based at NYUAD, Emily’s goal is to identify traits of Arabian Gulf corals that enable them to withstand extremely hot temperatures and apply these findings to assess potential climate change responses of corals in other regions.     View profile                                                                                                   Photo Gallery                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 View photo gallery [7 images]                                                                                                                                            Lab Manager     Grace Vaughan     Bangor University, UK. BSc, MSc                                                           Grace completed her MSc research project in Rodrigues,Indian Ocean where she formed a baseline study assessing the incidence of coral disease as well as assisting in public outreach activities and other research led by a local NGO. Since joining NYUAD in 2012, Grace has moved into the research field of coral reef fish & is currently involved in a number of projects looking at their ecology and physiology within both the Arabain Gulf and the Gulf of Oman.                                                                                                                               Research & Field Technician     Dain McParland                                                         Dain studied Marine Science at Colraine University, Northern Ireland and has taken part in several marine conservation projects gathering data on coral disease and fish species diversity along the Meso American Barrier Reef. As Research and Field Technician, Dain assists with logistics in both the field and lab as well as being the primary boat handler for the NYUAD boat. He has been a professional SCUBA diver and boat skipper since 2008 and held a passion for all things underwater a lot longer than that! Biology Lab                                               Lab members                                                          Lab members                                                     Lab members                              Publications                              News & Events                                                                              Principal Investigator   Dr. John Burt, Ph.D., Associate Professor of Biology                                                                                                                                   University of Windsor, Canada. PhD, MS     Cape Breton University, Canada. BS     University of Sunderland, UK. PGCE     A marine biologist, John Burt uses the Arabian Gulf as a natural laboratory to study coral reef ecology in extreme environments and to understand how these may serve as a model for the possible impacts of future climate change on reefs elsewhere.       View profile                                                         Post Doctoral Researchers     Dr. Ed Smith, Ph.D                                                                                                                                   University of Southampton, UK. BSc, PhD   University College London/Imperial. MSc     Ed's PhD looked into the role of green fluorescent protein (GFP)-like pigments in corals. Since joing NYUAD in 2012, he has been investigating the mechanisms used by corals in the extreme conditions of the Gulf, in the hope of improving the understanding of whether/how corals will adapt to future climate change. Ed is also looking at the population structure and connectivity of corals within and outside of the Gulf.     View profile                                                           Dr. Emily Howells, Ph.D                                                                                                                                   James Cook University, Australia. BSc   Australian Institute of Marine Science (AIMS) Ph.D     Emily's PhD evaluated the importance of algal endosymbionts in shaping the thermal tolerance of corals. While based at NYUAD, Emily’s goal is to identify traits of Arabian Gulf corals that enable them to withstand extremely hot temperatures and apply these findings to assess potential climate change responses of corals in other regions.     View profile                                                                                                   Photo Gallery                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 View photo gallery [7 images]                                                                                                                                            Lab Manager     Grace Vaughan     Bangor University, UK. BSc, MSc                                                           Grace completed her MSc research project in Rodrigues,Indian Ocean where she formed a baseline study assessing the incidence of coral disease as well as assisting in public outreach activities and other research led by a local NGO. Since joining NYUAD in 2012, Grace has moved into the research field of coral reef fish & is currently involved in a number of projects looking at their ecology and physiology within both the Arabain Gulf and the Gulf of Oman.                                                                                                                               Research & Field Technician     Dain McParland                                                         Dain studied Marine Science at Colraine University, Northern Ireland and has taken part in several marine conservation projects gathering data on coral disease and fish species diversity along the Meso American Barrier Reef. As Research and Field Technician, Dain assists with logistics in both the field and lab as well as being the primary boat handler for the NYUAD boat. He has been a professional SCUBA diver and boat skipper since 2008 and held a passion for all things underwater a lot longer than that! NYUAD Arts Center                                                            The NYUAD Art Gallery                                                                                                                            Breadcrumbs                                  Home                                               Research                                               Faculty Research                                               Marine Biology Lab                                                          Marine Biology Lab                                                     Lab members                              Publications                              News & Events                                                                              The Marine Biology lab uses the Arabian Gulf as a natural laboratory to study coral reef ecology in extreme environments and to understand how these may serve as a model for the possible impacts of future climate change on reefs elsewhere.                                                                             Current research seeks to examine how coral communities in these extreme environments respond to and recover from mass bleaching events, and how variation in environmental conditions affect biogeographic patterns of community structure of corals, fish, and other reef biota in the region. The current research of our 2 post-doctoral researchers focuses on molecular biology, coral physiology and coral reproduction to understand how corals cope in the uniquely extreme environment of the Gulf.                                                                                                                   Coral Reefs of Arabia: New insights & opportunities on our regional reefs                                                    February 15-17, 2015   Viiew the Agenda.  Register to be an audience member.
